channel.title: A community developed project?
channel.description:
Hello MoparScapers.
I've been wanting to do this for quite some time, but never really got round to it. We were going to do it with Xythax, but never bothered. I'd like to start it up though, have a handful of great developers who control the github we're using and control the requests and what not. This thread is more or less just a discussion to see if anyone would be interested or if it would just be thrown out the window.
So, discuss!

item.title: A community developed project?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:45, topic:456147”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=559089.msg4090460#msg4090460 date=1346279400]
If I thought it would be a success or be beneficial to the community I’d be all for it.
[/quote]
Welll… There was that idea that Taharok had a while back, where we made a scripting language centered around private servers That could be beneficial to the community.[/quote]

That would be useful indeed.

Also, I’ve started writing up a recruitment topic, should be finished soon.

Read full topic

item.title: A community developed project?
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:41, topic:456147”][quote author=asshole_rule link=topic=559089.msg4090419#msg4090419 date=1346276128]

I love you bro, but this will never work. Even if it did work, think about how It’d be…

Lol. 100 different styles of code in one API. That would be hard to work with.

Hence why you do it via github. That way, people can submit code and the project manager can standardise it

Still wouldn’t work, son.

How would it not work? Not everyone in the community would be accepted.

Stop trying to fight it, it wouldn’t work, there’s so many factors going into this. It would be horrible.
[/quote]

I’m not trying to fight it, I’m asking a question because you seem to be terribly against it.[/quote]

Ok well, why it wouldn’t work has already been stated.

Read full topic

item.title: A community developed project?
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

A lot of these projects fail because of bad project management. They get that scope creep and never look back.

If one of these were to start, it would need a strong leader to control everybody.

Person A needs to get this done, Person B needs to get this done by X day. If it doesn’t get done by the set deadline, find someone else. Projects like these really don’t have deadlines, that’s also why many fail.

Poor project management.

Read full topic

Jmood:

Read full topic

item.title: A community developed project?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:21, topic:456147”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=559089.msg4087578#msg4087578 date=1346016603]

Everyone has beef with someone, and this is why it won’t work. You’ll form a click of people who want to work on the base, and then you will have a click of people undermining them because they weren’t chosen to join or for whatever reason. You need to also be dedicated, and know exactly what you are dealing with. Writing a base is difficult, writing a base with a team is even more difficult. Before anything is written on paper, everything has to be documented in the client, and then the structure and design has to be decided. Frustrations will rise because it’ll take time, people may or may not quit leaving their work unfinished, and you may not have the time to lead. If you’re willing to go through with this, hats off to you.

uh, the real problem is lack of focus/organization…

Neither of these will be an issue if the leaders of the development are mature enough. For example, I would plan on having a founder/collaborator, someone who merely runs the project, a community manager if you will. An unbiased person who just focuses on making sure progress is happening and assigns all developers their respective tasks to stop overlapping, this person doesn’t have to have programming knowledge, regardless of language choices.

I would then have 3 possibly 4 very respected, very active, focused, mature Senior Developers. These developers will have extensive knowledge of the Java language, must be able to work smoothly in a team no matter who the other members are and must have the desire to leave something behind to the other members of the Mopar communities when they leave. These developers would preferably be badged Java Gurus. These developers also control the GitHub account, all requests must run past this team, even the Junior Developers must run their ideas and what they’re programming into the base past at least one member of this team.

I would then have 6 possibly 7 respected, focused and mature Junior Developers. These developers must also have extensive knowledge of Java and must be able to work smoothly with co-workers, no matter their differences. I realise all programmers have different skills and traits, but there must be certain things that will be agreed on, no matter the developer. These developers must have the desire to achieve and learn more and more within the Java language, as we all know, there’s always room for improvement. These members must be well-known around the MoparScape community and will be focused solely around this project.

After that, I don’t believe we need any other named programmers, the rest would be the community who would want to leave their piece of their code behind, and leave a part of them with this base for the future MoparScapers to use and see. This project, if it goes ahead, will be around MoparScape for years, this will be the first fully developed MoparScape source and we’d be the proud developers and collaborators of this project.

[/quote]
I think you seem to forget that something like this has been attempted by the more ‘mature’, ‘elite’ of moparisthebest. It failed. Honestly, it’s a lot harder to organize people and keep them on track (ESPECIALLY WHEN THEY’RE NOT GETTING PAID) than you think. The only people that really have time for such an adventure are those who’re not at university level or hold down a job; thus, you’re prone to a team of developers between the age of 12 and 18; which, usually leads to poor design and conflict.[/quote]

I realise that I would have a very, very hard job ahead of me. I also realise that it has been attempted before by people who outstretch my leadership and management expertise by a long run, but I also believe that with the right team it could be done. I realise everyone wants money and wants paid, they can look at it in a way that they could host the source once it’s complete and take donations that way and earn their rightful place. Or if we’re lucky, we could get programmers who just want to do it for the same reasons as myself, for the sheer point of leaving behind something that no-one will forget.

Read full topic
